results.title: Rescue by helicopter
results.creator_credit: Australian Commonwealth Film Unit, Australia. Royal Australian Navy, John Martin-Jones and Bern Gandy
results.brief_description: Standard procedures for rescue by a helicopter. Vertical take off and landing, and the ability to hover make it a valuable rescue craft. Shows correct method of approach, putting on the rescue strap, and giving the winding signal. Provided rules are adhered to helicopter rescue is quite safe. Edited by Richard Mitchell.

results.title: Requiem for a faith
results.creator_credit: Hartley Productions, Irving Hartley and Elda Hartley
results.brief_description: The traditional life of Tibet is depicted by Huston Smith, Professor of Philosophy at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. Smith shows the extent to which traditional customs have been invaded and corroded by the West. All social and economic activity revolves around religious practice. The importance of the Dalai Lama is emphasised. Set in Gyuto Tantric Monastery in Northern India, this moving film explores the essence of Tibetan Buddhism and focuses on the unusual chants of the Gyuto monks, whose training enables them to chant in chords. The film was shot mainly in Dalhousie, India, where the two Tantric Colleges, Gyuto and Gyume, were re-established in exile.

results.title: Requiem for a dream [DVD] (D)
results.creator_credit: Artisan Entertainment, Thousand Words Productions, Eric Watson and Darren Aronofsky
results.brief_description: Although the plot of “Requiem for a dream” revolves around four very human humans, the hero of the film is undoubtedly addiction. Addiction to food, to heroin, to diet pills, and that most everyday habit, to television. If film noir attacked The American Dream, then Darren Aronofsky’s follow-up to “Pi” sees that dream kidnapped, tortured and burned. This is exacted in the junkie lifestyle of Harry and his friends, as well as the loneliness of his mother, portrayed by Ellen Burstyn, whose performance makes “Requiem for a dream” one of the best movies of 2001. A victim to heroin chic but also, eventually, a critic, this film is aimed at a young audience but takes the unusual step of actually having something to say. The screenplay was written by Aronofsky and Hubert Selby Jnr (‘Last Exit To Brooklyn’), based on the latter’s novel. It also features one of the most progressive film soundtracks of recent years, written and performed by Clint Mansell and the Kronos Quartet.

results.title: Requiem by Andrew Lloyd Webber
results.creator_credit: BBC-TV, The Really Useful Group, Ian Squires and Humphrey Burton
results.brief_description: Filmed on location at the St Thomas Church, New York, on Sunday February 24th 1985, the world premiere of Andrew Lloyd Webber’s “Requiem” was performed to an enthusiastic and receptive audience. The wonderful voices of Placido Domingo (tenor), Sarah Brightman (soprano) and Paul Miles-Kingston (treble) supported by the Winchester Cathedral Choir (directed by Martin Neary), The St Thomas Choir (directed by Gerre Hancock) and the Orchestra of St Luke’s conducted by Lorin Maazel give depth and quality to Webber’s original composition.

results.title: Republic day: India
results.creator_credit: Films Division, Government of India and Ezra Mir
results.brief_description: The celebrations in Delhi on India’s national day, 26th January. The President drives in State to take the salute at a parade of armed forces, floats representing the various provinces and industries, folk dances and marching schoolchildren. Illuminations and fireworks enliven the city at night. The following day a fold dance festival shows the dances of many districts. The military ceremony of Beating the Retreat concludes the festivities.

results.title: Republic Day, 1955
results.creator_credit: Documentary Films of India and M. Bhavnani
results.brief_description: The pageantry witnessed in the capital on Republic Day. Colorful tableaux representing the achievements and developments of the national plans in different areas, the spectacular parade of the three units of the Armed Forces, and a brilliant display of fireworks.

results.title: Reptiles: a first film
results.creator_credit: Norman Bean Films, BFA Educational Media and George J. Holland
results.brief_description: Introduces basic information about the characteristics of reptiles: body temperature, skin types and habitats. Shows various reptiles in their natural environment including alligators, turtles, snakes and chameleons. Provides a recapitulation of the information presented. Suitable for middle and upper primary levels.

results.title: Reptiles of Western Australia
results.brief_description: Reptiles of four different types are shown: snakes, lizards, tortoises and turtles, land crocodiles, which are found in Western Australia. All are cold-blooded, and need the sun to warm them and encourage them to move. Close-up shots reveal the features of each type; the turtle’s skeleton attached to its hard back; fascinating lizards with frills, spikes or blue tongues; snakes’ markings and their fangs in action; fresh-water, harmless crocodiles and flesh-eaters which live in salt water.

results.title: Reproductive technology: facts and issues
results.creator_credit: Environment Audio Visuals, Neil Barrett and Jonathan Pearl
results.brief_description: This video is designed for students in years 10-12. Part one looks at recent technological advances in the field of reproduction and Part two raises some of the legal and ethical issues involved in such technology.

results.title: Reproduction of plants
results.brief_description: Reproduction of Liverworts, observed under a microscope. When an egg cell is fertilised it produces a new plant, the sporophyte, a capsule containing spores. Each spore produces a gametophyte which in turn produces a sporophyte. This “alternation of generations” takes place through countless generations of liverworts.
